greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = least positive k such that (2*n + 1) - 2^k is prime, or 0 if no such k exists.
comment: a(n) = 1 iff n is in A006254. - _Robert Israel_, Sep 02 2016
For n > 1, a(n) = 0 iff 2n+1 is de Polignac number, A006285. - _Thomas Ordowski_, Apr 13 2017
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
formula: If A188903(n) >= 2, then a(n) = log_2(A188903(n)), otherwise a(n) = 0.
example: a(14) = 4 because (2*14 + 1) - 2^k is composite for k = 1, 2, 3 and prime for k = 4.
mathematica: Table[If[n <= 2, 0, k = 1; While[! PrimeQ[2 n + 1 - 2^k], k++]; k], {n, 0, 120}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Sep 03 2016 *)
program: (MAGMA) lst:=[]; for n in [1..173 by 2] do k:=0; c:=k; repeat k+:=1; c+:=1; a:=n-2^k; until a lt 1 or IsPrime(a); if a lt 1 then Append(~lst, 0); else Append(~lst, c); end if; end for; lst;
(PARI) a(n) = my(k=1); while(2^k < 2*n+1, if(ispseudoprime((2*n+1)-2^k), return(k)); k++); return(0) \\ _Felix Fröhlich_, Sep 02 2016
results.author: _Arkadiusz Wesolowski_, Sep 02 2016
